div.p: LETTERS from the great Turke lately sent vnto the holy Father the Pope and to Rodulphus naming himselfe King of Hungarie, and to all the Kinges and Princes of Christendome.
Translated out of the Hebrue tongue into Italian, and out of the Italian into French and now into English out of the French coppie.
Imprinted at London by Iohn Windet, and are to be sold at the white Swan in Pauls-Church yard. 1606.

Annet Harioson by the grace of the high God most wel beloued in heauen, discended of the Line of the great Prophet Mahomet; Champion of Babilon, God on the earth, Barron of Turkie, Lord of the countrie of Iudea, euen vnto the earthly Paradise; Conqueror of Constantinople, and of Greece, Gouernour of the high and lower Seas, Commaunder of Hungarie and the future conqueror of Christendome. To the great Champion of Rome, and to his confederates the Princes of Christendome.

div.head: THE LETTERS LAST sent by the great Turke vnto the holy Father the Pope, and to Rodolphus, naming himselfe King of Hungarie, and to all Kings and Princes of Christendome.
div.p:
FOrasmuch as the great God of heauen, who raiseth & putteth downe Kinges, and causeth Monarchies most gloriously instituted and confirmed to indure at his pleasure, by the intercession and councell of the great Prophet Mahomet hath vouchsafed thorow his grace to exalt vs and our dominion aboue all Princes and principalities of the whole earth. Giuing vnto vs according vnto our valour, & to our most strong and most florishing armie, manifest and triumphant victories against all the enemies of our triumphant monarchie, fauouring vs by all meanes both by Sea and Land that we onely might raigne and gouerne. And farther, seeing that the earth belongeth to him which can conquer it, as the scripture telleth vs. Caelum coeli Domino, terram autē dedit filiis hom num; And furthermore since the great Mahomet, from whome we and our predicessors are discended, by good and lawful warres with the victories of the great God which wee
haue atchiewed, wee haue surpassed, and subiected to our obedience almost all the earth as well continent as the Sea coastes, that is to say in few wordes. The wise Grecia, The warlike Macedonia, The diuine Iudea, rich Egypt, strong Tartaria, The puissant and most redoubted Persia. Three and fiftie principalities with as many most rich and fertill Islandes, and to comprehend thē in general tearmes, first al Asia, then Africa & in a māner al yours, nay ours & not your Europa, weakened with wars & by vs possessed, & now of late the countrie and Cities of Hungarie, piercing into the countrie & bowels of Austria, the patrimony & inheritance of your Emperor: hoping to proceed euen vnto the end of your world towardes the west as well by Sea, as by Land, to the end wee may plant the authoritie of our most sacred and eternall Imperiall Maiestie, and Inuincible Monarchie.

Euen so to thee great Preest of Rome and to the Princes of thy lawe, and to those in league with thee, wee will, wee demaunde and commaund, that you submit your selfe vnto our most sacred & puissant Triumphing Triumphant mightie Monarchie, and the same submission manifest by homages and by reuerent tributes as to your Lord, which you shall accomplish and offer duly and iustly vnto our Imperiall Maiestie, as in reason, ciuilly and lawfully appertaineth.

And forasmuch as great Mahomet in his diuine Alcoran, saith that no Emperor, how mightie soeuer, can tame, nor subdue the courage or conscience of men,
although he may subdue and conquer all nations and countries. Therefore it hath pleased vs: and of our perpetuall authoritie and deliberation it is graunted vnto you, to vse your owne faith and lawe, and your accustomed ceremonies, euen as you haue done heertofore, which liberalitie and permission wee haue extended and giuen likewise to all Christians, and also to all others what religion or law soeuer they held liuing and inhabiting vnder our vniuersall Monarchie. For it is all one to vs what lawe or Religion the nations and people of the world vse and exercise, so that they bee obedient and subiect vnto vs. For thus our Prophet in his Alcoran witnesseth and saieth that it is pleasing vnto God, and wilbe singularlie adored and praised in diuers sorts of worldly religions of brute beasts and other creatures, as saith our Prophet, and yours also in his psalme Laudate dominum de coelis &. By meanes of which benefit, and graunt wee haue in short time subiugated, and brought to submission infinite nations and peoples; and hitherto almost the whole earth, and by the same meanes wee hope to be the onely Monarche of the whole earth before the expiration of two yeares, like as your owne Christians denying your law and imbracing a much better, haue diuined and prophesied to bee at Rome in the Chappell of Saint Basille.

Therefore beeware that you commit not that to your most great destruction, your singular domage and horrible subiection, which you may turne to your conseruation, great profit and acceptable liberty. But
open your gates Cities and townes vnto vs and to our deputies, & gouernours that they may take your others; And if you shall heerein faile: we declare and denounce vnto you mortall warres, destructions, firing of Citties and townes and other places whatsoeuer; generall occision and death both of olde and young, or else seruitude and slauerie; In which manner we are accustomed when wee subdue the nations and prouinces of the earth to proceede.

And you shall doe wisely to take ensample of the great Souldan of Babilon, who with his great riches and power was not able to resist vs, but we spoiled him and his house of their royall dignitie and dominion and cast him out of his Countrie, and lastly pursued him euen vnto death; likewise the great Cham of Tartarie, & al his friends and adherence were by vs subdued and all his subiects and Chaldeans, which now do serue and obey vs with great loyalty and affection.

p.hi: Moreouer, most renouned and redoubted Rodolphus vnto all christians, which affirme that they are beloued of the high God.

div.p:
By the declarations and reuelations of my priests and Sacrificers called Bramines in one of my most rich and famous Citties of the Indees, and that after a more strange manner admirable of one of my Gods of Apollo, iealous of the honour of the liuing God, which wee call Deumo whose picture by our permission is in manie
houses and places. The Bramines, whose office is to encence and perfume and present our prayers vnto Deumo, report that he hath affirmed that there is but one God, one law, and one King, euen as our forefathers haue foretolde vs. Wherefore we are resolued so to doe and to send vnto you our gouernours, to the end you may receiue our law and Alcoran, and the same shalbe effected with one hundreth thousand men which wee haue already sent to Sea to destroy you, and all christians, if so wonderfully you shall not make choise of our true religion ordained by our great Prophet Mahomet, except you yeeeld the tribute due vnto vs, as before we haue declared.

Denouncing vnto thee Rodolphus, which dost occupie my kingdome of Hungary, all euill and mischiefe and the ruin of all thy countries, kingdomes and dominions, because that thou takest vpon thee the name and title of a king. We sweare vnto thee by our crowne, to visit thee sooner then thou thinkest for, & to the end thou maiest the more assuredly knowe it, it shalbe with such an armie and force, that neither thou nor any of thy predicessors did euer behold the like. Wee doe already possesse the principal countries and Isles, which by our tyranny we oppresse & the inhabitants thereof, and we shall heerafter see, if the God in whome thou beleeuest can helpe thee, or saue thee (we meaning to destroy thee and all that shall assist or aide thee) with our inuincible armie, to the vtter confusion of thee and all thine with the most cruell death and tortures that possible we may

closer.dateline: Giuen at Constantinople, from whence wee banished thy first fathers, hauing most cruelly slaine them with their wiues and Children, rauishing the women and widdowes for the accomplishing of our pleasure. The 19. of our Natiuitie and the third of our Raigne.

div.p: Wee haue forced Vncassianus Assinbuis otherwise called the great Sophie of Persia and Lord of Armenia to yeelde obedience vnto vs, and to become our vassale and gouernour hauing made an indissoluble oath vnto vs, after he had first sent his two sonnes vnto vs for Ostages. By which agreement, made the last yeare, all the East Countries, and generally all Asia are in our quiet possession.

At which time we receiued courage, and resolued to conquer all Europe, and all the countries of Christendome. Which enterprize the most high and mightie Captaine Holofernus our most decre and welbeloued father minded with a most singular resolution to haue performed, And to this end we haue already trāsported the halfe of our most valiant forces into Europe, which are in number three hundreth thousand men, not reckening thirtie thousand Lansknights or Ganessars and as many other Christians which attend our artillery ordinance, and others which are the founders of our artillerie, and other Instruments of warre, which are of so great a number as the rest, all Renegados to fight in defence of our lawe, and with vs to conquer your country
Of these three hundreth thousand soldiers aforesaide, one hundreth and fifty thousand are already passed the Danubius, marching dayly forward, to inuade and win the Country of Hungarie, and all Germanie; and finally to pierce and draw vnto vs the noble countrie of France withall the countries adiacent and lying on the Seas. The other hundreth and fiftie thousand soldiours doe besiedge the strong Isle of Rhodes, from whence (I sweare by my great Patron Mahomet) they shall neuer departe vntill they haue yeelded the Castels; ports and fortresses which are in the saide Isle, for I will constraine and force them by famine, and other stratagems to make way vnto me, and to yeelde obeisance vnto me as vnto their true and naturall Lorde. Or it shall cost me fower hundreth thousand men, and the greatest part of all my riches. For the losse and expences are all one to me, be it soldiers, gould, or siluer, so that I may haue my will, and make them my subiects. Eleuē assaultes haue alreadie been giuen and, I beleeue, there wanteth verie little, to make them yeelde and to knowe our force and puissance, and after the Captiuitie thereof the way wilbee made verie easie into Italie and Spaine, that at my will and pleasure I may take possession of those Occidentall Countries and Regions, and to possesse the Castels, & Citties in all places, there to set forth, plant and display the most victorious and triumphant colours of our great Prophet Mahomet: And likewise his most worthie Image on the one side and ours on the other side grauen on all sorts of monies: To the end that out of our superabundance the remotest, and barbarous regions of the Occident may honourably acknowledge the most high Maiestie
like as the rest of the other Regions and partes of the world doe. And which I weare in my coate of Armes both beefore and behinde, and in the colours of my most noble Cauallerie, for a speale note, that by the consent of the whole earth, by the will of the high God of heauen and of the great Prophet Mahomet, I am the onely Monarche, and sole Prince vnder heauen in the shape of man, by similitude, and likelihoode according to the celestiall forme and shape.

Wherefore to conclude in few wordes I doe coūsel, aduertise, and commaund thee, great Priest of Rome, that without resisting heauen or earth, thou wilt receiue and obey our requestes and commaund, otherwise wee beeing accompanied with all the Kinges of the earth will come to see and visit thee, and wee will vse thy temples in Rome and other gorgious Churches of Christendome as wee did the Temple of the holie Sophie in Constantinople, and the Temple of Saint Basill neere to the mount Sinay; as also an infinite number of other Churches which wee haue subiugated to our pleasure.
No more at this present, but onely that wee desire answer, or for want of answer, we will vnderstand refusall, or refusing for vengance and Immortall warre.

closer.dateline:
Written from our Imperiall Cittie of Constantinople in the beginning of this moneth of March one thousand six hundreth and six, and the thirde yeere of our Ragne.
These present letters giuen to our chiefe King at Armes, to carrie them with safe conduct, and to returne vs an Answere.
closer.signed: Annet Harioson Great turke Emperour of the earth and ruler of the Sea.
